subject: Re: [junit] splitting this list
msgSnippet: I agree. There are those who seemingly are smart enough to subscribe to the mailing list, yet not wise enough to perform some simple search engine searching.

I agree. There are those who seemingly are smart enough to subscribe
to the=
 mailing list, yet not wise enough to perform some simple search
engine sea=
rching.

The best manner of dealing with them that I have seen, is to gentl=
y
welcome them to the world of JUnit, suggest that they start by reading
th=
e resources available at junit.org and that they then follow that up
with r=
eading one of the fine books available at their local or
Internet book stor=
e. And it never hurts to mention ESR's Smart
Questions essay.

That does ta=
ke a few minutes, but it's the nicest way to deal with
that sort of person =
that I've seen. This list is very friendly and
helpful and populated by som=
e fine people, so the last thing we want
to do is to seem judgemental or ru=
de. Products are judged by their
mailing list. Think of Perl, a scripting l=
anguage that is many orders
of magnitude more difficult to learn than JUnit=
, but it's mailing
lists are reputed for their friendliness. We should be t=
he same way.
Study how J.B. and some of the others deal with the beginner/u=
nwise
questions that come through the list.

Oh, and remember back to when =
you were confused and asking questions.
I try to keep learning new things s=
o I have no problem remembering
back to a day when I didn't "just know" the=
 answer. You should see
some of the stupid questions that I've asked over a=
t the Groovy
mailing list! But they are very kind and patient over there. W=
e
are/should remain that way over here. :-)

Simon

--
www.simonpeter.com

=
On 9/21/05, David Jackman <david.jackman@...> wrote:
> Unfortuna=
tely, I think the people who send a question without looking in
> the FAQ o=
r doing a simple Google search are also those people who would
> send the q=
uestion to both the simple and advanced group in hopes of
> getting a faste=
r response.
>
>
> ________________________________
>
> From: junit@yahoogro=
ups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
> Bradley, Todd
> Sent:=
 Wednesday, September 21, 2005 11:23 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subje=
ct: [junit] splitting this list
>
>
> Hi, I'd like to propose a controversi=
al topic, which is to somehow split
> up the JUnit email list into two list=
s - one for beginners and one for
> intermediate-to-advanced users.  I cher=
ish the discussion on this list
> about meaty topics of unit testing and us=
ing and extending JUnit.  There
> are some very smart people here!
>
> Howe=
ver, I frankly have reached the limit of my tolerance for stupid
> question=
s in this list.  And by "stupid questions" I mean the opposite
> of Eric Ra=
ymond's "smart questions"
> (http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.=
html).  There seems to be
> no end to the steady stream of new members who =
sign on and immediately
> ask a question that's already answered in the JUn=
it FAQ, which every new
> member automatically receives.  I know hitting th=
e delete key 5 or 10
> times a day isn't a huge deal, so I guess it's just =
the principle of it
> all.  I consider it rude for people to not have the c=
ourtesy to at least
> make an effort to help themselves.
>
> But I thought =
that rather than just unsubscribing from the list, I'd
> toss this message =
out to see if anyone else is in the same boat as me.
> There are supposedly=
 over 6000 subscribers, which sure sounds like a big
> enough population to=
 allow some specialization.  Alternatively, if
> dividing the junit@yahoogr=
oups.com list isn't likely to happen, does
> anyone know of a similar forum=
 for "intermediate-to-advanced" users of
> JUnit with a better S/N ratio?
>=

>
> Thanks for listening,
> Todd.
